indicators.justification:
The main website (Ministry of Environment - http://www.minamb.gov.ao/) that should provide information on the Government of Angola's climate actions does not work. It is almost impossible to know what actions are actually being taken to produce data about climate, projects or national initiatives.

However, it is known that Angola has been suffering from climate change. The southern part of Angola: provinces of Cunene, Cuando-Cubango, Huila and Namibe have been affected since late 2018 by severe drought.

In July 2021, the President of Angola visited those provinces to inaugurate a drought prevention system and protect the environment.

indicators.justification:
There is no reliable database on land in Angola. There is a Ministry of Territorial Administration but it does not have clear or detailed information about land. In 2019, the executive launched a project called 'Minha Terra' (My land) to secure access to land in Angola.

There is no final report on the programme 'Minha Terra' (My Land), but it is known that several land registrations have already been carried out.

For example, in April this year, more than 400 rural land concession titles were attributed in four provinces. There is no specific database of land registrations. However, there are few news reports published since 2019 about the government's programme.

The programme aims to ensure land tenure security, reduce the time taken to grant surface rights, simplify the process of land concessions and reduce the costs of the concession process.

Angola has recorded many cases of corruption in the public sector. Since 2017, the new president has been fighting against several cases of corruption and lack of public accountability, lack of public probity.

Despite its adoption in 2010, we have seen that the application of the public probity act still needs further dissemination, as corruption cases increase. The law obliges public officials to declare their assets, but this is often not done.

In 2019, the government launched a programme to recover public assets and money that was obtained through illicit means.

indicators.justification:
Angola peculiarly practices a dual legal system for data protection. While the Personal Data Protection Law makes copious procedural provisions for observance of data protection principles and enforcement of rights, a Presidential Decree effectively creates the office of Data Protection Authority to ensure compliance with the data protection law.

It regulates both manual and electronic processing of personal data by controllers and processors based in the country and processing activities by any means in the country irrespective of controllers' location. indicators.justification:
Law No 7/04 of 17 June 2004 is fundamental to understanding the electoral process in Angola.

In its article 94, the law states that the election campaign can be funded by: a) State contributions; b) contributions from the candidates themselves and from the political parties; c) donations from national individuals or corporate bodies resident or headquartered in the country e) contributions from Angolan citizens' national non-governmental organizations, under the terms to be regulated by the National Electoral Commission, or f) contributions from homologous parties, under the terms to be regulated by the National Electoral Commission.

In article 96, the same law states that candidates for elections must account for all income and expenses incurred in the election campaign within thirty days of the official proclamation of the results of the poll, indicating precisely the origin of the income and the destination of the expenses.

However, these provisions on electoral transparency are not respected by the different political parties. Since the creation of the law, the expenses and revenues of each political party are not known.

indicators.justification:
Angola has yet to pass a law on the right to information or freedom of information. The laws regulating the sector deal with freedom of expression and opinion.

For example, the Constitution of the Republic stipulates in its article 40 that everyone has the right to freely express, disseminate and share their thoughts, ideas and opinions, by word, image or any other means, as well as the right and freedom to inform, to be informed and to be informed, without hindrance or discrimination.

In addition, it is stated that freedom of expression and freedom of information have their limits such as the rights of all to honour and reputation, to image and intimacy of private and family life, protection of children and youth, State secrecy, legal secrecy, professional secrecy and other guarantees of these rights, under the terms regulated by law.

indicators.justification:
In 2020, the Angolan government has approved the Public Procurement Law (41/20 of 23 December). However, it is not clear how the data should be managed or published.

There is not much data on procurement procedures in many areas of governance, especially in the exploitation of natural resources, as there is still a lot of secrecy and little transparency.

We note that in June 2021, The first members of EITI Angola took office.

The EITI (Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative) is an international effort to fight corruption in revenues from oil, gas and mineral extraction.
